In command mode, press q and then the letter you want your macro to be saved as. You'll notice it says "recording" in the mode bar. Then do all of your commands, and then press q once more. Now you've recorded a new macro! To repeat it, just press @<the letter you chose>. Voila!
so you can compose/tweak your macro manually, then yank it to register "a", and use @a to run the macro
if you want to see a macro that you recorded into register "a", just do "ap
one of the neat things I recently learned about macros is that they're stored in a register as though you had yanked something into it with "ay (assuming you wanted the macro to be in register a)
